I am now come to the last part of this designe, wch is, to consider, how the 
Phaenomena of thin transparent plates stand related to those of 
all other Naturall bodyes. Of these bodyes I haue already told 
you, that they appeare of divers colours accordingly as they are 
disposed to reflect most copiously <s>by<\s> the rayes endu<s>[text?]<\s>ed with those 
colours. But their Constituc[i]ons, whereby they reflect some 
rayes more copiously then others, remaines to be inquired after.
And this I shall endeavour in the following Propositions 
Prop: 1. Those Superficies reflect the greatest quantity 
of Light wch haue the greatest refracting power, that is, wch 
intercede Mediums that differ most in their refracting densitie.
And in the confines of equally dense Mediums there is no 
reflection.
The Analogy between reflection & refraction will 
appeare by considering, that when light passeth obliquely out of 
one Medium into another which refracts from the p[er]pendicul,
the greater is the difference of their density, the lesse Obliquity 
is requisite to cause a totall reflexion; because as the Si<s>g<\s>nes are 
wch measure the refraction, Soe is the Si<s>g<\s>ne of incidence, at which 
the totall reflexion begins, to the radius of the circle, and 
consequently that incidence is least, where there is the great 
difference of the Sines. Thus in the passing of Light out of 
water into Air, where the refraction is measured by the ratio 
of the Sines 3 to 4, the totall reflexion begins when the 
angle of Incidence is about 48 degr 35 min. In passing out of 
Glasse into Aire, where the refraction is measured by the 
ratio of the Sines 20 to 31, the totall reflexion begins, when 
the Angle of Incidence is 40 degr 10 min: And So in passing out 
of C<s>h<\s>rystall, or more strongly refracting Mediums, into Air,
there is still alesse Obliquity requisite to cause a totall 
reflexion. Superficies therefore wch refract most do Soonest 
reflect all the light wch is incident on them, & Soe must be 
allowed most strongly reflective.
But the truth of this Proposic[i]on will further appeare 
by observing, that in the Superficies, interceeding any two of 
these Mediums, Air or water, or other liquors, Comon Glasse,
